body: My JIRA user name is "ppellmont"

@ajbozarth @jerryshao apologies, but I found an issue with the SIGINT handling in my code, which was concatenating lines of input together into a single command. I updated the loop to continue and reissue the `raw_input` call if a user submitted the ctrl-C command. This works far better and doesn't involve the raw writes to stdout which is a little nicer.
@meisam can you please address the comments, thanks!
@ajbozarth , would you please help to review, thanks!

The latest update still look fine to me, but I was wondering why there are so many extra blank lines in the file? Is it a python thing? Cause I've alway thought multiple empty lines in a row was bad style no matter the language.

@ajbozarth I may have gone a bit overboard but PEP8's guidance on blank lines says to surround top level functions and class definitions with two blank lines: http://legacy.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0008/#blank-lines.

Since there aren't any class members in here I split everything up with two blank lines.
I think @ericjperry is right, python code follows two blank lines convention between class definitions and top level functions, you can refer to pyspark code @ajbozarth .
Thanks, good to know more python style conventions :)

> @meisam can you please address the comments, thanks!

@jerryshao I addressed comments in the previous commit.
@ajbozarth @jerryshao is there any trick here to getting the tests to pass?
Usually just trying it again, I've never seen it fail this much before
@ajbozarth @jerryshao Tests passed!

Thanks, let me merge to master.

@meisam , thanks for comment, In our cluster, there are many http client, it's difficult to let all the client not submit create session request when too many session are being created. LivyServer should have the ability to protect itself.
 I will update the code according to your comment.
@ajbozarth thanks for your review, I will update the code according to the comment.
@shenh062326 are you using yarn cluster mode? spark-submit process is a short-lived process, it may not last very long.

@meisam rejection is another kind of throttle, what's your idea of throttle?

@codingcat, I saw you have a similar JIRA about this issue, what do you think about the current proposal?

@jerryshao , I use yarn cluster mode.

Beside this solution, what I can think of is to delay the session creation for throttling. Since POST request is async, so we could delay the session creation if reaching to threshold. Client side should wait and query until and session is created, what do you think of this solution?
@jerryshao The solution seems more friendly to client. But acturally we have have more than one livyServer, if too many create request send to one livy server, client may wait more time.
I get your point. I'm OK with current solution.
Please address the comments and add unit test to verify your code.
OK, I will add a unit test.

This kinda assumes Livy will always start client applications as child processes, which seems like an assumption that should be avoided.

Also, is this safe against command injections? If I set an env variable to `$(command to upload /some/sensitive/file)`, what will happen?

Finally, the change in `LivyClientFactory.java` also breaks API compatibility.

The purpose of this PR is to support different environment variables per session, but without this I cannot figure out another solution.

Yes it's true if we support launching SparkSubmit in one JVM then this will not be worked.

>Finally, the change in LivyClientFactory.java also breaks API compatibility.

> LivyClientFactory is Private, user will not touch it AFAIK.

Right, forgot about that.

Another question: what env variables are you thinking about here?

e.g., if a user sets `HADOOP_CONF_DIR` and Livy respects that, it's possible that the spark-submit launched by Livy will upload files to HDFS that Livy has access to, but the user shouldn't. That's another potential security risk.
For example some Python or R related env variables, like different PYTHONPATH/PYSPARK_PYTHON  per session.

Spark 2 at least has `spark.pyspark.python` which can be set in `SparkConf`. For others, one could use `spark.yarn.appMasterEnv.*` and `spark.executorEnv.*`, but the former assumes YARN cluster mode.

If really exposing this, you'll probably need to add some kind of configurable whitelist, and sanitize the user input, otherwise it's a bit risky.

@jerryshao I am sorry I did not see this before, but I am not sure whether the fix was required. The way we had it before, we could have created a different instance with a different time and we had a singleton with the default time.

A singleton's time cannot actually reflect the time of state transition, we don't know when this singleton is created, also in your previous patch, you change all the `SessionState` to singleton, it is not correct, once singleton is created, it will never change the time when you reuse it, it is the only copy in JVM, so using old state of reflect current session is not correct.

I understand that a singleton is a one time creation and does not reflect changes. That was the whole reason why I made that change. But that never restricted any of the `FinishedSessionState` objects being instantiated without the default values for the arguments. As an example, let's look at `Error`.

```scala
scala> :paste
// Entering paste mode (ctrl-D to finish)

sealed abstract class SessionState(val state: String, val isActive: Boolean) {
  override def toString: String = state
}
class FinishedSessionState(
  override val state: String,
  override val isActive: Boolean,
  val time: Long
) extends SessionState(state, isActive)
case class Error(override val time: Long) extends FinishedSessionState("error", true, time)
object Error extends Error(System.nanoTime)

// Exiting paste mode, now interpreting.

defined class SessionState
defined class FinishedSessionState
defined class Error
defined object Error

scala> Error
res0: Error.type = error

scala> Error.time
res1: Long = 2456992903279170

scala> Error(123L)
res2: Error = error

scala> res2.time
res3: Long = 123
```
Here you can see we have a default singleton for `Error` and we created a new object with a different value for `time`.

Yes, true. Your class and object definition is correct. But the way you're using it is not correct. For example: [here](https://github.com/jerryshao/incubator-livy/blob/761e574f6609b760c59f0ad890b0d895e85b5226/server/src/main/scala/org/apache/livy/server/batch/BatchSession.scala#L181) you're using singleton object `Success` instead of class object `Success()`, so the time of `Success` state is not as expected, this singleton object may already be initialized before, using the `time` from this object cannot actually reflect the session's success time.
Okay. Now I get it. Makes sense.
Thanks! Merging to master.
